definition: lit. an old ox licking its calf (idiom)/fig. (of parents) to dote on one's children

prefix used before the surname of a person or a numeral indicating the order of birth of the children in a family or to indicate affection or familiarity/old (of people)/venerable (person)/experienced/of long standing/always/all the time/of the past/very/outdated/(of meat etc) tough
surname Niu
ox/cow/bull/CL:條|条[tiao2],頭|头[tou2]/newton (abbr. for 牛頓|牛顿[niu2 dun4])/(slang) awesome
to lick/to lap (up)
calf/sacrificial victim
the love of a cow licking her calf (idiom)/parental love
lit. the solicitude of the crow (who provides for his old parent)(idiom)/fig. filial piety
lit. the cow licking its calf fondly (idiom)/fig. to show deep affection towards one's children
burning beanstalks to cook the beans (idiom); to cause internecine strife
couple living in destitute misery (idiom)
lit. the heart of a sheep in the skin of a tiger (idiom)/fig. impressive in appearance but lacking in substance/braggart
to kill a pig as a lesson to the children (idiom); parents must teach by example
lit. to hang one's books on cow horns (idiom)/fig. to be diligent in one's studies
lit. when one grass burns the other grass sighs (idiom); fig. to have sympathy with a like-minded person in distress
lit. when one grass burns the other grass sighs (idiom); fig. to have sympathy with a like-minded person in distress
as close as flesh and bones (idiom); deep friendship
a single day apart seems like three seasons (idiom)
lit. to open one's liver and drip gall (idiom); wholehearted loyalty
to escape from the tiger's mouth (idiom)/to have a narrow escape
lit. a chicken and a bottle of wine (idiom); fig. ready to make an offering to the deceased, or to entertain guests
to see the ox already cut up into joints (idiom); extremely skilled/able to see through the problem at one glance
brotherly affection
